It'll be great in my truck or in a kitchen drawer though, where accidental presses will be rare and where I won't need to turn on the light RIGHT NOW.

Both of my problems could be fixed entirely with the addition of some kind of raised protector around the switch

reviews:
Okay, so first off I'll start with the kudos, just to be a nice guy: this is a very bright little light, and the battery life is downright impressive. It's very useful... when it works.

My main beef is with the button that controls the whole thing. As other reviewers have said, it's pretty finicky to find, especially one-handed. Also as mentioned by other reviewers, it's a lot easier for your chair, other tools on your belt, etc. to find and switch on this light, for some odd reason. More than once I've been somewhere and someone will go "hey, uh, your waist is strobing," and I'll pull out my burn-inducing flashlight from the holster, which now has a spot at both ends (depending if I was carrying it head-up or head-down) where the nylon fibers are all fused and stiff.

But the worst thing of all is that it just plain didn't stand up to EDC usage. I work mostly indoors/daytime, so I only use this light maybe once a week, and yet after about a month and a half on my belt, the button started to hang up sometimes, and in less than three months (of being carried constantly but relatively seldomly used, mind you), the crown of the button popped out entirely. The way it's designed, the button cuffed into the barrel of the flashlight, and it was supposed to hold the post of the switch in, not vice versa. Now I have to decide if I want to glue it and possibly cause the button crown to accidentally tear the post out (and maybe bring the electronic board with it.)

Three months is apparently past Amazon's claims window, but I've submitted a ticket to Fenix to see if they'll warranty it. Will try to remember to update review accordingly.

review_title: Bright and lightweight. Awful switch! Lousy holster.
reviews:
Very bright and versatile light, compact and lightweight. The pure cylinder shape rolls off tables quite easily. The charge port cover is so tenacious that it keeps out not just dust and moisture but also your fingernail when you try and pry it open. Fortunately you don't have to charge this light all that often with normal use. The side-mounted switch is irksome and fussy. Hard to find by feel but easy to press by accident. It can be locked out if you remember to do so: press it twice in quick succession and the light will blink twice, and will thereafter only turn on briefly when you press the switch. If you again press the switch twice in rapid succession it will unlock and you can then turn it on with yet another press. But once you press the switch to turn it on, the next press will either increase the brightness, or if you hold the press for an instant too long it will turn off. If you turn it on and quickly press the switch the light will increase brightness in five steps and then go back to low setting. If you want to turn it off you have to press the switch once but not too quickly or it will just change brightness, and not for too long or it will start strobing. If you don't remember to lock out the switch when you put it into the flimsy piece of trash the manufacturer supplies as a holster, it's very likely that you will inadvertently press the switch in a way that turns the light on, where it will then melt thru the cheap nylon of the flimsy trashy holster. Or it will commence to strobing until the battery dies or someone points it out to you, or you feel the heat thru the flimsy trashy holster, or see the light thru the hole melted in the flap of the flimsy trashy holster. Do that awkward dance for a while, maybe a year or two and the switch will fall completely out of the flashlight. I don't know how the warranty service will be but I guess I'll find out, because I got a return authorization to send it in (at my own expense) once I sent them the serial number so they could figure out if I bought it legit or something. We'll see, and I'll update this review at that time.
(Edit:update 11/19) The switch was not repairable so I eventually received an entire new-in-the-box flashlight including all the accessories. It’s the same bright light with the same complicated control scheme, in the same flimsy, trashy belt pouch. I melted a hole in the replacement within a week of putting it back into service. Oh well, chalk it up to user error. I probably won’t set the couch on fire with it if I exercise due caution. Wish me luck!

review_title: I hate that I didn't buy this sooner...
reviews:
What a load of crap!!!! ...that I didn't discover Fenic sooner!

I'm a backcountry and Airshows pilot (WilgaBeast) and I put flashlights through hell. This thing is the most well constructed small frame torch I've ever had the pleasure of owning.

I've already dropped it out of the airline (accidentally as I was using it to spot for coyotes) from about 300 feet. No problem, it was on, so my guys on the ground grabbed it for me. It survived landing in a rock wash.

Bloody hell, great job.
